introduction.p: You may have heard, The world is constantly changing. But the big question is How? Is there a pattern? In math, patterns have names.

Linear is the name of a pattern. If you graph a linear formula, it looks like a straight line. If you look at the data of a linear pattern you will notice the data has a constant rate of change in other words constant slope.
In this section we study a pattern in which something remains constant, but it's not the rate of change, it is the percent change.
One way to distiguish between linear and exponential patterns is linear means repeated addition. Where as exponential means repeated multiplication.

We can pick out patterns from language too. For instance the statement, A worker makes \$ 15 per hour is giving us information about a linear pattern. The statement indicates that for each hour that passes the worker adds \$ 15 to their earnings.
On the other hand if the worker has a salary increase of 15 \% each hour it means their earnings are multiplied by 1.15 for each hour they work.
We must realize that multiplication and percent change are related. To change a value by a percent we multiply that value by something.

subsection.title: Review of Percent Change
subsection.p: A percent change on a value means to change it by a fraction of itself.

When someone gets a 10 \% raise in salary it means that their salary was divided into pieces and one of those pieces is added onto the original salary. The percent value 10 \% means \frac{\displaystyle{10}}{\displaystyle{100}} = \frac{\displaystyle{1}}{\displaystyle{10}} The increase means 0.10 of their salary is added back onto their original salary.
Think of it like this

blockquote.p: New Salary = Old Salary + 1/10 of Old Salary
New Salary = Old Salary + 0.10 of Old Salary

In the equation N = 1.1s the number 1.1 is called the growth factor and is usually denoted with letter b.
In this example multiplying by the growth factor of 1.1 makes s bigger by 10 \%
In order to make calculations with a percent value we must turn that value into its decimal equivlent so we can use it.

In fact, the decimal equivalent of any percent value is that value divided by 100.
A percent increase means to multiply the original value by b = 1 + r where r is the decimal equivalent of the given percent.
In our salary example the raise of 10 \% has a decimal equivalent r = 0.1 so we multiplied by b = 1 + 0.1 = 1.1 to get the 10 \% increase.

subsection.p: Just like something can increase by a percent, it is possible to decrease by a percent.

Consider a pair of shorts on sale where the original price of the shorts has been reduced by 15%. This means the price of the shorts is divided into pieces and one of those pieces is subtracted from the original price of the shorts.
To reduce the price by 15 \% we must turn the percent value into its decimal equivalent. The decimal equivalent of 15 \% is r = \frac{\displaystyle{15}}{\displaystyle{100}} = 0.15.
Therefore the sale price of the shorts is

blockquote.p: New Price = Old Price - 0.15 * Old Price

subsection.p: Something to consider about a percent decrease is, How much can we decrease? Let's think about that for a moment.
If you have 10 apples, you can eat 50 \% of them, that's half the apples. You can eat 75 \% of them, that's 7 \frac{1}{2} apples. You can even eat all the apples, that's 100 \% of the apples!
But, can you eat more than all the apples you have? If you only have 10 apples, you cannot eat more than 10 apples, you cannot decrease by more than 100 \% of what you have.
Therefore when it comes to a percent loss, the growth factor is less than 1 for sure, but it cannot be less than 0.

Furthermore, since muliplying by zero is zero, it makes the growth very uninetesting. From now on a growth factor is always strictly greater than zero. The only choices are to be greater than 1 or between 0 and 1
In math we say percent growth means b \gt 1 and percent decay is 0 \lt b \lt 1

subsection.title: Constant Percent Change
subsection.p: We now know in order to change a value by a percent, we need to multiply that value by a growth factor b \gt 1 (increase by a percent) or 0 \lt b \lt 1 (decrease by a percent).
By the way, what happens when you multiply by a factor of 1? [Hint: Nothing happens, which is also very uninteresting. So we don't include b = 1 as a possible growth factor.]
In the exercises below, find the percent change in the given expression.

statement.p: Given 22(1.39) what is the percent change on 22?
Given 7(2.41) what is the percent change on 7?
Given 17(0.56) what is the percent change on 17?

solution.p: Multiplying by 1.39 is a percent . The growth factor is greater than 1 as in b = 1 + r. To find r we subtract, r = b - 1 then multipy by 100 \% to get the final answer.
Multiplying by 2.41 is a percent . The growth factor is greater than 1 as in b = 1 + r. To find r we subtract, r = b - 1 then multipy by 100 \% to get the final answer.
Multiplying by 0.56 is a percent The growth factor is less than 1 as in b = 1 - r. To find r we subtract, r = 1 - b then multipy by 100 \% to get the final answer.

subsection.p: Using the fact that a percent change is a multiplication we can take any two values and find the percent change between them.
To decrease a value by a pecent we multiply by a growth factor b = 1 - r.
To increase a value by a percent we multiply by a growth factor b = 1 + r.
In each case r is the decimal equivalent of some percent value.

subsection.p: At this moment the word countable may seem strange. It means, A quantity you can count or put on a number line, like 12 or 205 or or 50,235,678 or even 3 billion.

You must be wondering, What's not countable? Well, how about infinity? Infinity is not countable. You cannot count to infinity and it's not something you can put on a number line. We'll talk more about infinite compounding later.

subsection.p: Comparing the linear and the exponential graphs there are some clear differences. The linear function graphs as a staight line while the exponential function graphs as a curve.

In our example both functions have the same initial value. This value shows up as the vertical intercept on each graph. But the exponential function decreases faster than the linear function. Then again, the linear function has a horizontal intercept (it touches the horizontal axis). Does the exponential ever touch the horiontal axis?
Let's explore the graph of the exponential function more closely. Keep in mind the example of the ant moving towards a wall by reducing the distance by 25 \% each minute.

statement.p: Notice that the graph seems to touch the x-axis at t = 16, but if you zoom in around that point we realize the graph does not actually touch the horizontal axis. How far to the right should you move the point in order to touch the horizontal axis. Try zooming in again, does it touch the horizontal axis? In fact, the graph will never touch the horizontal axis. In this case, the time, t axis is called a horizontal asymptote. A horizontal asymptote is a horizontal line that the function approaches as we move to the right or to the left.

subsection.p: All exponential funcitons have horizontal asymptotes. The equation for a horizontal asymptote is the equation of the horizontal line the function approaches.
